g.text: terminated surfaces. However, the introduction of planar
defects parallel to the polar surfaces can decrease the surface
energy and stabilize different crystal morphologies, as has
multiple twin defects, this explanation might also be applicable
to the nanospikes investigated herein. A growth model for
ZnO nanospikes from a partially molten Zn source including
such mosaic and multiple twinning has been proposed by
(2009). They described the initial twinning of
condensate seeds and further coalescence and intergrowth of
individual spikes, resulting in a mosaic twinned structure with
a tapered shape. Very similar growth conditions are believed
to apply during the ﬂame-transport process.
A large population of basal-plane stacking faults is
observed in the specimen cross sections, as indicated by arrows
in Fig. 4. Note that the observation of this defect type is
exclusively enabled by the cross-section view. Twinning on the
planes was observed more frequently than on the
planes and often appeared to divide the nanospikes
into smaller domains. In addition, shorter boundaries were
observed featuring both types of twin. This is in agreement
with theoretical energy calculations for twin defects in wurt-
During the HRTEM investigation, severe beam-damage
effects under observation with an unmodiﬁed electron dose
led to dissipation of the carbon matrix and subsequent release
of the specimen into the microscope. Further, the very thin
specimens suffered rapid material loss due to electron knock-
on damage, as demonstrated by the large void in the centre of
the cross section depicted in Fig. 4(
a reduced electron dose is highly recommended for cross
sections embedded in a carbon matrix.
Models based on a supercell approach were designed for
, on the basis of previous studies (Hrkac
The supercell approach involved the following three steps,
(i) The initial wurtzite-type (superscript W; hexagonal cell,
) was transformed into an orthohexagonal cell.

pp. 78–89), the unit-cell transformation of the ideal structure

obtained by applying the transformation matrices

(ii) A superposition structure (SPS) was created by adding
the atomic coordinates from an unmodiﬁed supercell from
nanospike cross sections along their growth direction, which is
The spikes contain a high density of twinned domains (red dashed lines
represent twin boundaries) and basal-plane stacking-mismatch defects
